name: Rolling Stones for Beginners Trivia Game | Rolling Stones | 10 Questions

questions.text:
These are lyrics from which Rolling Stones single?

"I'm gonna tell you how it's gonna be 
You're gonna give your love to me 
I'm gonna love you night and day."
questions.explanation:
Not Fade Away.

	"Not Fade Away" was a hit for the Rolling Stones 1964. It featured on the 1966 album "Big Hits (High Tide and Green Grass)". Buddy Holly recorded the original version of "Not Fade Away", written by Charles Hardin (Buddy Holly!)and Norman Petty, in 1957.The Rolling Stones took their name from the Muddy Waters song "Rollin' Stone Blues".

questions.text:
"I met a gin soaked, bar-room queen in Memphis
She tried to take me upstairs for a ride. 
She had to heave me right across her shoulder 
'Cause I just can't seem to drink you off my mind."

Which Stones track contains these words?
questions.explanation:
Honky Tonk Women.

	The Stones topped the US and UK charts with "Honky Tonk Women" in 1969. This song, the story of a prostitute, was lifted from the group's "Let it Bleed" album. "Honky Tonk Women" topped the charts in both the US and UK.

questions.text:
Can you identify this song?

"When I'm drivin' in my car, and the man come on the radio 
He's tellin' me more and more about some useless information 
Supposed to fire my imagination."
questions.explanation:
(I Can't Get No) Satisfaction.

	"(I Can't Get No) Satisfaction" was written by Mick Jagger and Keith Richards. Keith Richards created the distinctive lead guitar sound using a Gibson Fuzz Box.This track satisfied the record buying public, getting to the top in both the US and UK charts in 1965.

questions.text:
"You better stop, look around, here it comes, here it comes, here it comes, 
Here it comes. Here comes your nineteenth ____________."

Which words are missing from this Rolling Stones lyric?
questions.explanation:
nervous breakdown.

	"19th Nervous Breakdown" featured on the 1966 album "Big Hits (High Tide and Green Grass)". Mick Jagger was inspired to write this track while on a particularly hectic tour in the USA.The single got to number two in the UK charts. The Stones 1963 line-up was Mick Jagger, Keith Richards, Bill Wyman, Brian Jones and Charlie Watts.

questions.text:
Which 1960s hit single is this?

"I was born in a cross-fire hurricane 
And I howled at my ma in the driving rain 
But it's all right now, in fact, it's a gas 
But it's all right."
questions.explanation:
Jumping Jack Flash.

	Another tune credited to Mick Jagger and Keith Richards, as were most of the group's hits, although it is claimed the Bill Wyman wrote the majority of this track."Jumping Jack Flash" appeared on the 1969 album "Through the Past, Darkly". It jumped to #3 in the US charts and #1 in the UK.

questions.text:
"How does it feel 
How does it feel 
To be without a home 
Like a complete unknown 
Like a ____________?"

You may not associate this track with the 'Stones', but they did record a version of it. What two words are missing?
questions.explanation:
rolling stone.

	"Like a Rolling Stone" appeared in the UK singles chart in 1995. This track, written by Bob Dylan, featured on the album "Stripped".The Stones were signed to Decca Records UK in 1963.

questions.text:
"She would never say where she came from 
Yesterday don't matter if it's gone 
While the sun is bright 
Or in the darkest night 
No one knows, she comes and goes
Goodbye..."

In which Stones song will you hear these lyics?
questions.explanation:
Ruby Tuesday.

	"Ruby Tuesday", another Jagger and Richards composition, featured on the Stones "Flowers" album in the UK and "Between The Buttons" in the US. A live version of this track was released in the UK in 1991.

questions.text:
"Don't you worry 'bout what's on your mind - Oh my 
I'm in no hurry I can take my time - Oh my 
I'm going red and my tongue's getting tied - tongue's getting tied 
I'm off my head and my mouth's getting dry 
I'm high, But I try, try, try - Oh my." 

What are the Stones trying to say on this one?
questions.explanation:
Let's Spend the Night Together.

	The Stones hit the charts with "Let's Spend the Night Together", in 1967. This controversial track was banned by many radio stations because of its sexual content.The single charted at #1 in the US and #3 in the UK. "Let's Spend the Night Together" appears on the UK album "Flowers" and "Between The Buttons" in the US.

questions.text:
"______  ______, how come you taste so good? 
______  ______, just like a young girl should."

These two lines should give you the title of this track. What two words are missing?
questions.explanation:
Brown Sugar.

	"Brown Sugar" was a chart topper on both sides of the Atlantic in 1971. This track, about African slaves, featured on the album "Sticky Fingers". The album cover, designed by Andy Warhol, featured the picture of blue jeans with a real zipper.The Rolling Stones first single, "Come On", was released in 1963.

questions.text:
"Well baby used to stay out all night long 
She made me cry, she done me wrong 
She hurt my eyes open, that's no lie 
Tables turn and now her turn to cry."

You could say this is an appropriate question to end this quiz on.
questions.explanation:
It's All Over Now.

	The Stones released "It's All Over Now" in 1964. It was originally recorded by US group The Valentinos. A UK #1 this song got to #26 in the US. The Rolling Stones have been inducted into the "Rock and Roll Hall of Fame", and received a "Grammy Lifetime Achievement" award in 1986.
